paragraph_text: WizeTherapy was established in 2007 and provides Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy and Speech Pathology services for babies, toddlers, children, adolescents and young adults. At WizeTherapy all sessions are tailored to meet your individual needs. We have a great team of caring professional staff with a passion for working in paediatrics. We work with you (and your child) to develop realistic goals for therapy sessions that maximise functional abilities and enhance quality of life. Most therapy occurs at our modern and fully equipped practice in Booragoon and we also have an outreach clinic in Lesmurdie. We can provide services in any environments where you or your child participate in daily activities such as home, school, day care or other community settings if required, such as scouts, gymnastics, or work settings, etc.
WizeTherapy’s mission is to support and promote development, achievement and participation for children, adolescents and young adults. We aim to do this by:
• working together with clients and families in a way that best meets their individual needs;
• offering high quality, evidence based contemporary therapy services; and
• undertaking training and research activities that supports the community in providing opportunities for all children, adolescents and young adults.

WizeTherapy employs skilled clinicians who use a transdisciplinary approach to work with families. A transdisciplinary team involves therapists and family members working together collaboratively. This approach incorporates a high level of communication as all members work towards a set of common goals that direct intervention. The transdisciplinary team model is seen as a family friendly approach operating within a family centred model of service provision. This enables the team to provide a truly comprehensive service that is tailored specifically to the unique and individual needs of the child and their family. Families are always members of the team and are respected and valued as equal members. It is important to know that the family is always the final decision maker.

Private fee-paying clients can access WizeTherapy’s services without a medical referral. However, if you have a referral from a health professional or medical practitioner please bring this to your appointment.
Clients eligible for Medicare funding/rebates under a Medicare plan must provide a Medicare referral for allied health treatment.

WizeTherapy is offering a Pilates movement program that offers both land based and reformer exercises for children as young as 2 years of age. Our program allows children to work efficiently with improved motor control. The program is ideal for children with hypermobility, motor co-ordination difficulties, hypotonia, movement modulation difficulties, reduced kinaesthetic feedback or general weakness.
Additional complimentary neurodevelopmental approaches combined with reformer based exercise can also be beneficial for children with neuromuscular conditions.

Designed by Wize Therapy’s, Senior Physiotherapist, Jodie Kariyawasam, this important clinical intervention for children and young adults uses a specially modified Pilates Reformer to improve mobility, function and participation in activities of daily living and in the community.

The Reformer is comprised of a movable platform that has a series of pulleys and springs attached, enabling users to perform assistive or resistive exercise sequences across a variety of positions and through multidirectional planes of movement.
Most importantly, it’s so much fun, children are asking to come back again… and again.
For more information on our clinical Pilates service, please contact us and one of our friendly staff will answer your questions or book your consultation.

WizeTherapy provides physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech pathology to young children with disability. The team has extensive experience in working with children with specific diagnoses such as Cerebral Palsy, Down syndrome, Autism Spectrum Disorders, Intellectual Disability, Global Developmental Delay, Fragile X and other chromosomal disorders. Therapy services involves the provision of specialised services for infants, toddlers and children with developmental delay or an identified disability to maximise their participation in their chosen family, school and community activities.
For young children and children attending primary school we offer:
• Holistic and thorough assessment of child development within the family and community context.
• Comprehensive language and communication assessment and, if appropriate, recommendations for AAC (Augmentative and Alternative Communication).
• Mobility assessment and, if appropriate, recommendations for mobility aids.
• Sensory exploration and sensory processing and, if appropriate, recommendations for aids and equipment.
• Fine motor, visual motor and visual perceptual assessment and, if appropriate, recommendations for aids and equipment
• Assessment of independence skills in a range of self-care areas such as eating and drinking, (including swallowing), toileting, and dressing.
• Assessment of buildings and homes and recommendations for modifications to enable access and optimal function within these environments.
• Assessment of the school environment and recommendations to enhance participation.
WizeTherapy also has speech pathology and clinical psychology services available to carry our diagnostic assessments for families seeking to determine if their child has Autism.
Our Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy and Speech Pathology  services can be accessed at our Booragoon, Atwell and Kelmscott clinics.

White Zebra Foundation is the not for profit arm of WizeTherapy. It was created to assist families who have a child with a disability to maximise their participation in life through increasing access to specialised therapy services such as physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech pathology.

The foundation aims to provide financial support for families with a child with disability who are unable to access therapy services due to financial hardship. We hope to assist families to receive therapy support as required by their child with disability to promote their functional skills and abilities across a range of life areas and environments.

The Foundation was set up in December 2010 and through a variety of fundraising activities has so far been able to sponsor four children by providing therapy free of charge for a limited period of time. The White Zebra Foundation will continue to raise funds to support those children with limited access to therapy services.
For more information on the White Zebra Foundation please head to our news section to read more. For information on donating or getting involved, please contact us on the link below.
We’d like to say a very big thank you to the White Zebra Foundation past and present partners, for their kind and generous support.

Sometimes children may just need an ‘extra hand’ to meet their developmental milestones such as gross motor, fine motor, language and communications. Our therapists provide physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech pathology services so that your child can communicate well in all environments, achieve their potential academically, have fun with indoor and outdoor play, and interact socially and emotionally with their families and others.
Some common concerns of parents of babies, toddlers and children that paediatric physiotherapists at Wize Therapy can assist with are:
• Babies who have flat spots on the back of their heads and/or difficulty turning their heads.
• Babies who are having difficulty tolerating tummy time.
• Babies and toddlers who seem to be slow in achieving motor milestones such as rolling, sitting, crawling, standing and walking.
• Toddlers who have bow legs, pigeon toes, or knock knees.

Our physiotherapy team has extensive experience in working with children with specific diagnoses such as Juvenile Arthritis, Perthes Disease, Osgood-Schlatter Syndrome, Hypermobility Syndrome and sporting injuries. In addition, some common concerns of parents of young children in primary school that paediatric physiotherapists at WizeTherapy can assist with are children who display the following challenges:
• difficulties with co-ordination, balance, walking and running.
• difficulties climbing and playing on playground equipment.
• difficulties with strength and endurance during physical activities.
Some common concerns that our paediatric occupational therapists at WizeTherapy can assist with are:
• Babies who are not feeding or sleeping well.
• Babies who are having difficulty tolerating tummy time and using their arms to support themselves.
• Babies and toddlers who seem to be slow in achieving fine motor milestones such as reach, grasp and release.
• Babies and toddlers who are fussy and difficult to settle.
• Toddlers and children who are clumsy, show poor coordination and poor exploration during play.
• Children who seem to be showing difficulties with using two hands in a coordinated way.
• Children who seem to be showing difficulties with strength and endurance during play activities.
• Children who seem to be slow in achieving pre-literacy and early school skills.

• Babies and children who seem to be showing difficulties an over-reaction or a lack of reaction to certain sensory experiences, eg. sensitive to smells or tastes, over-reactive to certain touch experiences, does not experience pain, fidgety and wiggle more than others, etc.
Some common concerns that our paediatric speech and language pathologists can assist with are:
• Babies who are not feeding well.
• Babies who are having difficulty developing first words and/or signs of communication.
• Toddlers and children who seem to show delayed use of verbal and non-verbal language during play.
• Toddlers and children who seem to show fussy and resistive eating behaviours.
• Children who seem to be slow in achieving pre-literacy and early language skills necessary for school success, including articulation and comprehension.
• Children who show difficulties with articulation and sound production.
• Toddlers and children who seem to show delayed social skill behaviours.

The Qigong Sensory Protocol (QST) is a protocol for children with ASD and sensory challenges and is a patting massage designed to improve circulation of the skin and the rest of the body, which is quite different from western massage. The direction of the massage is done away from the head, towards the hands and feet, and thus follows the direction of blood flow and brings oxygenated blood to the skin and sensory nerves.

Chinese medicine believes that children with ASD and sensory challenges are often less aware of their environment and of their bodies because they have blockages in the sensory channels which affect the way that a child can take in information from the environment. The goal of QST is to clear the blockages to the senses so that the child becomes more aware and is then able to learn. Primary studies in QST have shown:

We pride ourselves on delivering services which meet evidence-based best practices for children and young adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder.

Our Senior Occupational Therapist Deborah Thomas is now qualified to provide a new intervention for children with ASD, which has recently had strong positive outcomes, published twice in the Autism Research and Treatment Journal, 2015.

Qigong Sensory Protocol is a protocol of massage which has been developed over the course of 14 years and 10 peer-reviewed research studies and is based on Chinese medicine. Qigong massage has been used for over 3000 years to treat medical conditions and improve health in children.

The Qigong Sensory Protocol (QST) is a protocol for children with ASD and sensory challenges and is a patting massage designed to improve circulation of the skin and the rest of the body, which is quite different from western massage. The direction of the massage is done away from the head, towards the hands and feet, and thus follows the direction of blood flow and brings oxygenated blood to the skin and sensory nerves.

Chinese medicine believes that children with ASD and sensory challenges are often less aware of their environment and of their bodies because they have blockages in the sensory channels which affect the way that a child can take in information from the environment. The goal of QST is to clear the blockages to the senses so that the child becomes more aware and is then able to learn.

Our therapists have expertise in running group sessions in the classroom, focusing on targeting skill areas (eg. pencil grip, story re-tell, gross motor play), in liaison with the classroom teacher, for a set number of sessions. For example, the OT may run a fine motor group targeting pencil grips, 45 minutes weekly, for 5 weeks. The groups are planned, organised and run by the therapist, and support the curriculum.

WizeTherapy therapists can complete individual student assessments related directly to access to the curriculum, eg. Assessments in High School to support Curriculum Council applications; literacy and processing assessments across all ages; or sensory processing assessments across all ages. These assessments can be completed on-site (travel costs will be additional) at the school, or in the clinic rooms in Booragoon.

Our team of therapists are able to provide individual sessions on-site during school hours. In order to offer this service, we would require a minimum number of families who would be interested in this service (eg. 6-10 families interested in speech pathology sessions on-site, or 6-10 families interested in occupational therapy sessions on-site). The contract can be either between the family and WizeTherapy, with the school providing space and basic equipment (desks and chairs) for the therapy to be carried-out; or a contract with the school for a certain hours of therapy provision per week.

Holiday Groups can be held and facilitated by our therapists. These groups are run under the supervision of a trained therapist and are designed to address developmental concerns affecting school participation and performance, eg. literacy development, social skills, sensory regulation skills.
For more information on these services or to make a booking, please click on the link below.

WizeTherapy is a private practice in Booragoon which specialises in providing speech and language therapy, occupational therapy and physiotherapy services to children who require extra support in reaching their developmental milestones, in the school and classroom environment as well as at home and in the community. WizeTherapy can provide a range of services for schools, depending on the staff and student needs. With increased expectations placed on teachers in the classroom, decreased time before and after school and increased pressures on families, it can sometimes be difficult and confusing to know a) whether the student is reaching his or her milestones in order to participate at his or her best in the classroom; b) whether the students needs need to be met by extra therapy supports; and c) how the child’s needs will be fully met to have success at school.

WizeTherapy provides a school screening service to identify children at risk of difficulties in their typical development in the most critical periods of schooling during the early, middle and high school years. Overall, screenings would briefly assess the foundation skills across the three main developmental areas of fine motor, gross motor and speech and language skills. It will identify those students who may require further detailed assessment and intervention support. The professionals at WizeTherapy can work closely with the student, staff and family members to provide appropriate assessment and intervention if needed.
Screening is proposed to last approximately 30 minutes in duration per group.
Screening is proposed to last approximately 45 minutes in duration per group.
In the older children (Grade 2-5) handwriting speed, legibility, basic comprehension, problem solving and composition parameters will also be screened.

In high school students (Grade 8-11) the screening will briefly assess handwriting speed, executive functions and language components of compositional writing. It will identify those students who may require further detailed assessment and intervention support.
The professionals at WizeTherapy will work closely with the student, staff and family members to provide appropriate assessment and intervention if needed.

In the early years (Kindergarten and Pre-primary) screenings will involve assessment of each child’s expressive and receptive oral language skills, speech, early phonological awareness and word meaning relationships.

Grade One screenings will involve assessment of each child’s ability to tell stories with particular focus on their grammatical usage and sentence formation, oral language, sound/letter correspondence, higher level phonological awareness skills and speech.

Middle school screenings (Grade 3) will involve assessments of oral language, reading (including reading fluency, accuracy and comprehension), storytelling and writing, problem solving and high level phonological awareness skills.
The professionals at WizeTherapy will work closely with the student, staff and family members to provide appropriate assessment and intervention if needed.
In the older children (from Grade 2-3) higher balance skills, movement timing, co-ordination, sequencing and movement composition will also be screened.

In the Upper Primary (Grade 7) the screening comprises of postural analysis, strength, dynamic balance, visual motor coordination, fitness and flexibility. It will identify those students who may require further detailed assessment and intervention support.
The professionals at WizeTherapy will work closely with the student, staff and family members to provide appropriate assessment and intervention if needed.

Wize Therapy strongly believes that feedback, including complaints, suggestions and compliments, are crucial to ensuring effective and high quality service delivery and the continual improvement of services and systems.
What kind of feedback can you give?
You can choose a support person to assist you with your complaint or feedback. This person can be a friend, family member, staff member or an advocate from another organisation.
Wize Therapy is committed to resolving complaints in an ethical, confidential, timely, transparent and fair way.
We view feedback as a positive opportunity to improve the quality of our services and operations, and to strengthen relationships with our clients and with our community.

Complaints are treated confidentially. Only the people who need to help find a resolution will be involved. Wize Therapy’s Quality Review Committee ensures the processes are followed in an appropriate and timely manner.

This week is very special for us here at WizeTherapy, as it’s been 10 years since we opened!

Over the last 10 years, we’ve been blessed to work with so many amazing families and therapists. We would like to say thank you to each and every one of you who has been part of this incredible journey!
Here’s a message from the compassionate and inspirational lady we are lucky enough to call our Director, Paula Dyke. This is how it all began!

‘I established WizeTherapy after resigning from my role as a Senior Manager in a large disability organisation, to assist in caring for my father who was dying of a brain tumour. Following his death, I felt I could no longer work in such highly political environments, where the ability to make changes and ‘make a difference’ was a continual challenge.

I felt there was a need for a ‘one-stop shop’, where families could easily access all three therapy services of Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy and Speech Pathology. So, myself and a small group of highly skilled therapists opened the doors of WizeTherapy in a small shop front in Marmion Street, Myaree. We began without a single client and 10 years later hundreds of clients have used our services.

The last 10 years have been both extremely rewarding and challenging. It has been rewarding in being able to play a significant role in assisting children and adolescents and their families to achieve their goals. It has also been rewarding to be able to provide the opportunity for employment to therapists in difficult economic times. It has been challenging primarily in terms of financial survival. Without the belief in what I was trying to do and the associated financial support of my family and close friends, there are at least three occasions where WizeTherapy would not have survived. It is not a business, due to the nature of services provided, that will ever make a lot of money, but it is a business that has now consolidated financially and more importantly, is making a contribution to the community that we are very proud of.

I say WE as the reputation of WizeTherapy has been built on the expertise and commitment of many therapists and administrative staff who have worked for the organisation over the 10 years. Thank you to all who have supported us in our journey so far, and we look forward to providing many more years of service to the community.’

Across Australia, The National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) has commenced in various launch sites. This is a different way of providing support to individuals and families living with disability, where the individual/ family has choice, control and flexibility around accessing supports. Funding, where required, is provided to individuals (‘individualised funding’) rather than to organisations (‘block funding’).
The Commonwealth and Western Australian Governments signed an agreement in order to start a two-year trial of the NDIS in Western Australia. This trial commenced in the Perth Hills in July 2014.
This trial is occurring alongside the State Government’s WA NDIS My Way model which has commenced in the Lower South West region with the Cockburn-Kwinana area joining in July 2015.

Trialing both schemes will mean service users and families will ultimately be the beneficiaries of the best possible delivery model for Western Australia, with an independent evaluation occurring on both trial schemes.

Developing an Individualised Plan is central to the NDIS process and will be one of the first things undertaken with the assistance of a planner. This plan is then used to determine what sorts of supports you might require and whether there are any funded supports as part of that plan. Therapy would be considered a funded support.

WizeTherapy is a registered service provider under the NDIS for the Hills trial site, this means that you can choose to access Wize for therapy support. Families can also ask to have therapists from Wize involved in the development of your Individual Plan to help ensure it captures all of the support being provided and that it reflects your goals and aspirations.
If you live in the Perth Hills click on the link below for more information on available NDIS services.

Put simply, yoga is about connecting the mind and the body by using physical postures and the breath. In traditional forms of yoga, the aim is to reach a spiritual ‘nirvana’ or to cultivate compassion through awareness of your own thoughts, feelings and motivations. It can also be a wonderful way of maintaining physical strength and flexibility and to relax. Yoga is all these things to me and that is why I want to share it with others, including the many children who come to me as an Occupational Therapist.

Yoga originally comes from India and has been practiced for centuries as a spiritual path to enlightenment. More recently many ‘western’ scientific studies are showing the physical and mental benefits of the practice for children, as well as adults.
The Yoga 4 Classrooms website has an
of well researched benefits, including that yoga:

As a regular yogi, I often use the practice in therapy sessions with my young clients. I use it to address difficulties with coordination, balance, midline crossing and the integration of the two sides of the body. I also use it as a tool for self regulation by teaching children that yoga can be a way to cope with stress and anxiety.  I use it mostly as it is fun and playful and leaves you with a happy feeling. It is always great to see my little clients leave with a smile on their face!

Paula has worked in the health and disability sectors for over 30 years. She originally trained as a Physiotherapist, undertook a further degree in Psychology and in 1999 completed her Masters in Public Health Degree. She spent several years working as a physiotherapist with children with disabilities and their families in both metropolitan Perth and remote and rural regions of Western Australia before moving into Senior Management positions. In these positions Paula managed large teams of physiotherapists, occupational therapists and speech pathologists providing services to children with disabilities and their families in large not-for-profit organisations.

Paula now leads the team at WizeTherapy along with undertaking a range of research and project consultancy work within the sector. Paula has had her research work published in a number of reports and internationally peer reviewed journal articles. Paula is passionate about ensuring the services provided by WizeTherapy are contemporary, evidence based and of a high quality.

Everyone seems to be talking about ‘Mindfulness’ or ‘Meditation’ these days! It’s what all the ‘cool kids’ and the ‘hipsters’ are doing, but what really is it? When I first came across mindfulness I thought it was all about people sitting cross-legged, humming in a circle. I quickly decided it wasn’t for me, but this is not what it is! Mindfulness can be done by anyone, any age, anywhere and in almost any activity. Mindfulness is a way of being aware of our own thoughts and feelings and learning to live in the present moment to clear our minds of anything else. It can be adapted to suit any given problem and can be used by children and adults in a range of ways, depending on the setting.
Here are just some of the areas mindful activities can provide support:

We live in a fast-paced, technological world where children are constantly faced with new experiences and challenges. Sometimes children may be unsure how to cope with these stressors and can demonstrate fearful or anxious behaviours. It’s a natural reaction to want to protect your child from things that make them anxious, but avoiding the anxiety trigger can make things worse as it may reinforce our anxieties. A little bit of stress and anxiety is ok but when that anxiety stops your child engaging and participating in the things they need or want to do, mindfulness is here to help. Mindfulness helps children focus on the present moment and temporarily forget about their worries (this can be anywhere from 60 seconds – 60 minutes depending on the mindful activity and how new you are to mindfulness). Try our mindful glitter bottle activity below to help your child manage anxious behaviours or worries!

Living with chronic pain from illness or injury can be an emotional and physical strain. Children can experience feelings of frustration, anger and depression due to the pain they experience daily. Although medication can be useful to manage their pain, sometimes they may need something extra to help them feel like they are in control. Mindfulness can be this ‘something extra’. It can help to change the way their mind perceives the pain, making it more bearable to live with. ‘Body scanning’ activities have been shown to be really beneficial for pain management strategies in children and adults. Why not try using our mindful glitter bottle activity to help your child deal with the thoughts and worries associated with their pain.

Bullying and cyber-bulling is becoming more and more prevalent everyday across Australia and the world. No parent wants to see their child get bullied or for their child to become the bully. Mindfulness and focusing on the ‘now’ can be used as a way to reduce and prevent bullying. It has been shown as an effective management tool for the victims, bullies and witnesses by helping them develop a greater awareness of themselves, their feelings and giving them a greater ability to regulate their emotional responses to events. The culture of bullying is based on reactive behaviours: children often bully others as a way of gaining control over external events happening in their lives and their own feelings of powerlessness; those who are victims to bullying can react in ways that perpetuate bullying as the bullies receive the reactions they are seeking. Are you worried your child is being bullied or becoming a bully? Use our mindful glitter bottle to provide a calm, safe and supportive environment for your child, offering them the opportunity to open up and let go of any negative feelings they have experienced recently or in the past.

Is getting to sleep a common problem for your child? Bed time is when the mind can come alive, whether you want it to or not! Having a poor night of sleep can have a detrimental effect on your child and waking them up to get ready for school can seem an impossible mission! They then get sent off to school with their internal battery only partly charged, possibly leading to difficulties focusing and paying attention in class, poor control of their emotions and also possible increased conflicts with their peers. So how can you help your child get a better night of sleep? Mindfulness of course! Introduce the mindful glitter bottle as part of your child’s bedtime routine to encourage calm and relaxation before bed!

Do you find your child has difficulties recognising their own and other people’s emotions? Do they find it hard to differentiate between different feelings? The capacity to do this is known as ‘emotional intelligence’: the ability to identify and manage our own emotions and the emotions of others. Mindfulness helps increase ‘emotional intelligence’. It can improve how children understand their own emotions. Mindfulness increases a child’s ability to control their emotions and also supports them to recognise the emotions of those around them. Take the first step to develop your child’s emotional intelligence with the mindful glitter bottle. You can use the glitter bottle to discuss your child’s feelings and help them understand that their emotions (positive or negative!), are valid and learning how to deal with them makes a big difference.

Starting a new school, going into a new year group, homework and exam time can be overwhelming for any child! There are so many worries involved around school and education. Worries and the increasing educational demands on children can make school a negative experience and this can inhibit learning for children. Have you ever found that your child comes home from a busy day at school and just ‘explodes’ or has a ‘meltdown’? Mindfulness can help provide a coping strategy to reduce these behaviours and help your child to deal with worries. Try and make time in your morning and evening routine for the mindful glitter bottle. It only needs to be as little as 60 seconds to start with! You can encourage your child to learn this coping strategy in a safe environment, so it can then be transferred into the more demanding school environment on a daily basis.

It’s common for people to tell me they feel they don’t spend enough time with their children. In today’s society everyone seems to be constantly on the go and consequently making time for ‘quality time’ seems to get pushed to one side as there’s always something else we should be doing! Our to-do lists are endless! Mindfulness can help strengthen the relationships children have with others as it’s a quick and easy way for them to sit with an adult and be mindful together. Besides, who couldn’t do with an extra few minutes of peace and quiet in their day?! Having this extra few minutes every day, just for you and your child, will not only increase your bond but also strengthen your child’s ability to form emotional connections with others. You can try introducing the mindful glitter bottle into your daily routine. Perhaps you can sit down with your child as soon as you get in from the school run, or when you get in from work. When you do it isn’t important, but just spending that few minutes together can make a massive difference to your child’s overall wellbeing!

The more often you and your child can practice being mindful, the more beneficial it will be to you both. Remember, there doesn’t have to be a ‘problem’ in your child’s life before you practice mindfulness. You can start learning to be mindful at any time, and teach your child a technique to let them be in control of their own wellbeing.
Take a look at our mindful glitter bottle exercise below! This is a fun and easy way for you and your child to get creative and design your very own mindfulness tool!
1. Fill the bottle 3/4 of the way full with water.
2. Now put the bottle of glitter glue into the bottle.
3. Fasten the lid on the bottle nice and tight and shake so all the glitter separates and spreads around the bottle. (this may need to be done a few times)
4. Add food colouring if you desire
Think of the bottle as your mind, and the glitter as all the thoughts in your mind.
Step 1 – Start to take slow deep breaths, in through your nose and out through your mouth. Keep this breathing up throughout the activity.
Step 2 – Shake the bottle nice and hard so the glitter is moving all around the bottle. Make sure the lid is on tight! We don’t want any accidents!
Step 3 – Look at the glitter swirling around the bottle, and imagine the glitter as the swirling thoughts in your mind.
Step 4 – Put the bottle down in front of you and continue to breath slow deep breaths, in and out.

Step 5 – Watch how the glitter slowly starts to settle to the bottom of the bottle. Take a minute to stop and be still like the bottle. Let your thoughts slowly sink in your mind like the glitter sinking to the bottom of the bottle. Just wait and be still.
Step 6 – When the glitter settles at the bottom of the jar, the water is clear, just like your mind. Now you are calm and can focus again because your mind can see clearly.

Practicing this will help you every day when your mind feels all full of glitter (thoughts). All you need to do is go and get the glitter bottle and shake it up so it looks like all the thoughts swirling around in your mind. Then put the bottle down and stay very still while you watch the glitter and your thoughts become calm and clear again.

WizeTherapy now offers individualised goal-directed intensive therapy support programs for rural and remote families.
These intensive therapy support programs are often the perfect option for families living in rural and remote locations, who are only able to stay in Perth for a short period of time.

All of our intensive therapy support programs are delivered at least three times per week, over a predefined period of time. WizeTherapy’s intensive therapy support programs are generally delivered over a period of two to six weeks, depending on the family’s preference.

Your family will have access to a dedicated trans-disciplinary team of therapists consisting of a Physiotherapist, Occupational Therapist and Speech Pathologist. Your family will have the same therapy team throughout your intensive therapy support program.
Initially, your therapy team will assess your child and work with your family to set specific short-term goals that will shape your child’s individualised intensive therapy support program.

Most importantly, your child’s therapy team will work closely with you and your family (siblings included!) to ensure that you return home with a greater understanding of exactly how to continue to work on your child’s specific goals. Once you return home, we recommend that your family liaise via teleconference on a regular basis with your therapy team to ensure that your child’s progress continues.

White Zebra Foundation is the not for profit arm of WizeTherapy. It was created to assist families who have a child with a disability to maximise their participation in life through increasing access to specialised therapy services such as physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech pathology.

The foundation aims to provide financial support for families with a child with disability who are unable to access therapy services due to financial hardship. We hope to assist families to receive therapy support as required by their child with disability to promote their functional skills and abilities across a range of life areas and environments.

The Foundation was set up in December 2010 and through a variety of fundraising activities has so far been able to sponsor four children by providing therapy free of charge for a limited period of time. The White Zebra Foundation will continue to raise funds to support those children with limited access to therapy services.

From waking up to going to school and playing with friends and family, a day in the life of a child is filled with a wide range of experiences. With these experiences brings the opportunity to experience a wide range of emotions. For some children, these emotions can be overwhelming and have an impact on being able to fulfil their important job of being a child. If this relates to your child, than using The Zones of Regulation is for you and your family.

The Zones of Regulation is an evidence-based program, designed and created by Occupational Therapist, Leah Kryupers. The program focuses on the following areas to support and facilitate a child’s emotional regulation:
2. Supporting the child to understand how their emotions impact on their brain, body and others.
3. Exploring and implementing the specific tools to support a child’s emotional regulation.

The Zones of Regulation is increasingly being implemented in a number of schools throughout Western Australia. The tools and strategies are designed to not only develop a child’s cognitive understanding of how to support their emotions, but to also provide families with a number of strategies that can be used in whichever environment they may find themselves in.
Who is the program suitable for?

The Zones of Regulation is suitable for both typically developing children and children with a disability or delay. The program can be used with children as young as five up until the early teenage years.
If your child is experiencing difficulty with recognising and/or managing their emotions, than this is the program for them!
Where to purchase the program: The program can be purchased from the
If you feel that your child’s emotions and how they manage these feelings is impacting their life (and yours!), you are not alone.
WizeTherapy to arrange for an appointment to further explore your child’s emotional regulation difficulties and get some practical strategies to implement into your daily life.

Movement, sensory and motor skills play an important role in our everyday life. They are the fundamental building blocks for so many activities that a child participates in at home, school and in the community.

Children with Autism often present with difficulty around communication and social participation, with support often provided by your Speech Pathologist and Occupational Therapist. What many families don’t realise, is that physiotherapy can help too!
While physiotherapy is mostly known for helping with mobility, strength and gross motor skills, it may just be the missing key for that tricky task your child can’t quite master!

Sensorimotor skills involve the ability to take in sensory input (including taste, smell, vestibular, hearing, touch, vision and proprioception) and produce an appropriate motor output or movement that allows a child to be successful in activities and tasks at home or school.
Some of the areas your Physiotherapist can support your child:
How to know if my child needs physiotherapy?
These are just a few things you may notice if your child needs support with any of the following areas.
· Does your child have difficulty with social interactions in environments that challenge motor skills (e.g. the school playground)?
· Does your child find extended tasks such as engaging in mat time difficult?

· Does your child fatigue throughout the day? This may present towards the end of the day as decreased speech clarity, increase tripping/falling, increased time to complete tasks or increased challenging behaviours etc.
· Does your child appear clumsy or is accident prone?
· Does your child have a hard time mastering new skills?
· Does your child need assistance with sequencing the steps to complete a task? For example, while dressing or tying shoelaces?

It is more challenging for a child to negotiate obstacles in their environment safely if they are unaware of their body’s position in space. They may have difficulties with social interactions due to not being aware of personal space, or how to appropriately engage with peers.
· Does your child often hug people or touch them without asking?
· Does your child appear to not be aware of other people’s personal space?
· Does your child find gross motor tasks such as kicking a ball, climbing stairs or running more challenging?
· Does your child avoid uneven or challenging floor surfaces and/or play equipment that is unstable?
· Does your child seek or avoid tasks such as car rides, swings, and/or spinning? This may indicate that they need increased or decreased vestibular input.
· Does your child often slouch while sitting or lean on objects to support their body in an upright position?
· Does your child speak softly or need to take breaths regularly while speaking?
Your Physiotherapist can review and support the development of these skills as well as many more. It is important we lay the foundation for success!
If you would like to learn some ideas and strategies to support your child’s development of these foundation skills,
join me on the 13th of October for a FREE WizeWorkshop.

A great website I recommend to my clients is
. This was developed by a fellow speech pathologist from Perth, and matches books to a child’s age.

This is a free and sometimes under utilised resource people forget about! Many local libraries offer story time sessions or activities for a variety of ages. My children loved going to story time sessions and at the end I encouraged them to find a book they liked to take home.

Reading can be as fun and cool as you make it. Let me know how you go!

Now that the winter chill has well and truly set in, so can the boredom blues! When it’s cold and raining outside, it’s not always the best place for little people to play, but it is important for your child to stay active. It’s time to get creative with the following five ways to keep your children active over winter!
Time to let your child’s imagination run wild!
Animal walks that will help develop your child’s strength in their arms, legs and core include:

Get the kids to help set up the obstacle course with you. Create an obstacle course around the house that involves climbing up, crawling under, jumping, hopping, walking on a tightrope (i.e. tape on the floor), stepping over objects and rolling.

Here’s an example: crawl under the coffee table, walk over a pile of stepping stones (cushions), jump over a piece of string, tip toe walk along a tightrope, and finish with throwing a balloon into a bowl on the bench!

Just like the common party game, play some of your child’s favourite music. Start dancing but remember to freeze when you stop the music! This fun game will help your child learn to control their movements, build up strength and balance skills.

The classic game of Twister ® is relatively cheap to purchase from a variety of toy stores. Your child’s aim is to stay standing as long as possible, no matter how twisted they end up! It a wonderful way of helping their motor planning and coordination, while building up their strength.

Take it in turns to be Simon. Simon should challenge your children to jump, hop, squat, and balance. You can add in movements that use two hands (bilateral movements) or crossing midline (using their hands on opposite side of their body). But remember don’t do it if Simon doesn’t say!

Challenge your child to try and make every letter of the alphabet with their body. It will help them to learn where their body is in space, build strength and flexibility, and learn the alphabet at the same time! Sometimes, looking in a mirror can make things a bit easier!

Using masking tape, mark out the shape of a ladder on the floor. Your child can jump, hop, run, side step, tip-toe walk or do the grapevine, making sure to step in each square only once! For an extra challenge, put a beanbag or a ball in a square that your child has to stop to throw, then continue their way through the ladder.

These activities work on gross motor skills, strength, motor planning, coordination, balance and body awareness, all while keeping your little people busy! Have a go, be creative and prepare to get active!

Cutting is a complex, yet necessary skill for school. It requires your child to co-ordinate two sides of their body whilst executing refined, coordinated movements with their arms and hands. WizeTherapy Occupational Therapist, Olivia Firth has put together seven simple ways you can work with your child to develop and improve their skills outside of the classroom.

When holding scissors, ensure your child has their thumb positioned in the small hole of the scissors, on top of the larger hole with their other fingers. The non-dominant or supporting hand holding the paper should also have the thumb positioned on top. Try using the rhyme “thumbs on top to chop, chop, chop!”, to help your child remember this.

The general progression of cutting follows being able to open and shut scissors, snipping the edge of paper, cutting straight lines, cutting curved lines, cutting simple shapes and then progressing to increasingly complex shapes. Don’t try and master everything at once! Just practice opening and shutting the scissors to start with.

Practice cutting materials with thick and varying textures such as old birthday cards, paper plates, leaves, play dough, grass, curling ribbon and straws. This will provide your child’s hand with increased feedback to the muscles and joints, assisting with the development of fluidity and accuracy.

Practice doing big snips or ‘chomps’ and little snips or ‘nibbles’, with your child. I like to use an analogy of a shark for ‘chomps’ (big snips) and a fish for ‘nibbles’ (little snips). Chomps are used when the scissor blades are closed completely and nibbles are used when the scissors are only closed partially. Typically, chomps are used at the beginning of a long cut and nibbles are used as you near the end.

Use thick, bolded lines on the shape or line your child is cutting out. Drawing simple shapes or lines using permanent marker can be a helpful way to do this. If your child is practicing the control of stopping their cutting, then you can use a sticker to show them where they need to stop.

It is helpful to use the same words with your child while cutting. Singing the song ‘Open, shut them, open, shut them, give a little snip’ can be helpful prior to commencing a cutting task. This song reinforces the cutting movement pattern required.
Little bits of practice is better than one large chunk of practice. Here’s some ideas of how to incorporate scissor skills into daily life and routines!

As a teenager growing up, a lot is changing.

Being a teenager is trying out new experiences, new behaviours and new ideas. It is a time of transition and marks the years between being a child and being an adult. If you’re a teenager and have a disability, sometimes there can be additional things to tackle.

But becoming an adult and becoming independent is not about having to do EVERYTHING for yourself. It’s about knowing when to ask for help. It’s about starting to become proactive. It’s about taking more responsibility for yourself.

The Children’s Music Workshop: An introduction to learning language through music!
Growing up in a musically rich environment is often advantageous for children’s language development. Music can be used to help enhance language skills across all ages and abilities.

The Children’s Music Workshop demonstrates how to include music in practical ways to facilitate language acquisition in children. Merging language and music together creates an educational, interactive and fun way to encourage each child to communicate effectively.
Join us to find out how you can incorporate music and songs into your child’s learning environment to facilitate language skills at home.

Music has a powerful presence in our everyday lives. It’s used to influence and create an atmosphere and often becomes part of routines and special occasions. You probably wouldn’t go a day without hearing some form of music, whether it be in the car, at the shopping centre or on the T.V. It’s incorporated into entertainment, storytelling, a way of expressing emotions and creativity, and is also a great way to develop speech and language.

Using music in Speech Pathology includes any form of music whether it be listening, singing, playing or dancing. Music is a fantastic way to engage your child and teach them a variety of new words and sounds. Music also encourages children to watch, listen, copy and make requests. It’s also a great way to introduce the different sounds in words and to explore rhyming words. Music is an amazing tool for helping children learn new vocabulary/signs and communication skills as well as bringing lots of joy.
1. Music and language are universal and unique to humans.

Everyone reserves the right to be able to communicate their needs and interests. Music can be used to learn the vocabulary to do so. Music is a great way to learn new words, especially for those children learning alternative ways of communicating (e.g. key word sign).
2. Music facilitates learning of new vocabulary in a variety of forms of communication (verbally, key word sign, communication boards or icons).

Music can serve as a powerful tool in learning new vocabulary. Songs and nursery rhymes immediately engage children and are repetitive in nature. Being repetitive allows the child to hear and practice key words over and over again. Practice is important to learning new signs/words and children love to practice songs at home, in the car or with friends at school. The learning of new words can be transferred between multiple forms of communication; be it through signing, verbal language, writing or pointing at pictures.

Children and parents do not need to possess the skills to play an instrument or have musical knowledge in order to participate in activities that include music. You don’t even need to be a good singer, it is about having fun!

You do not need to purchase anything to be able to practice these skills at home. A Speech Pathologist can provide families with songs, actions or Key Word Signs, and additional ideas and advice on how to practice!
5. Music is suitable for all ages.
All ages can participate in learning songs! Nursery rhymes are perfect for young children and popular songs on the radio can be used with older children.
6. Music can be beneficial culturally and socially.

Music is seen across different cultures and languages. Songs can be tailored to cultural backgrounds and traditions (e.g. storytelling) so that learning of vocabulary can be relatable and functional. Songs can also be practiced with family members and friends which can aid in developing social interactions and bringing people together.
7. Music can be beneficial across many developmental areas including speech/language development, social skills, fine motor skills, memory and gross motor skills.

Practicing actions/Key Word Signs and songs can indirectly aid in developments in areas other than language development. Using a Key Word Sign or action can aid in fine motor development and children will often enjoy dancing and moving to songs which may facilitate gross motor development.

Music is in our blood. It is nostalgic and makes us laugh, cry, smile and share common experiences. By including it in our learning experiences, we are creating connections between having fun and learning, which should always be the ultimate goal throughout therapy!

About the writer: Miranda is an enthusiastic and creative Speech Pathologist at WizeTherapy who is passionate about working with children and adolescents with speech, language and communication difficulties. She also has a keen interest in music and how it can be used in her therapy services in a fun and functional way.

Children experience a wide range of emotions every day. For some children, understanding these emotions, the impact the emotion has on their body and how to best support themselves, can be particularly challenging.

The Zones of Regulation is a program designed by Occupational Therapist and Educator, Leah Kuypers. The program is being used by families, schools and therapists to foster children’s emotional awareness and regulation.
Join our Occupational Therapist, Olivia Firth, to learn how to use this program and resources to help your child today!
In this workshop you will learn how to:
Use the Zones of Regulation terminology in your everyday life.
Learn about the different tools your child can use to support their emotional regulation.

A trust established to honour brothers who had a neurological disability has awarded $28,000 to a program that aims to improve children’s mobility.
WizeTherapy's mission is to support and promote development, achievement and participation for children, adolescents and young adults.

PERTH – 20 MARCH 2015 – Local not-for-profit organisation, The White Zebra Foundation, was this week presented with a cheque for over $28,000 to implement a pilot program using Clinical Pilates for children with physical disabilities.
Donated by the Jon and Barry Brealey Trust, the grant money will be used to develop and deliver an intensive paediatric Clinical Pilates program using Reformer technology.

Designed by Wize Therapy’s, Senior Physiotherapist, Jodie Kariyawasam, the nine-week program will initially work with six children using a specially modified Pilates Reformer to improve mobility, function and participation in activities of daily living and in the community.

The Reformer is comprised of a movable platform that has a series of pulleys and springs attached, enabling users to perform assistive or resistive exercise sequences across a variety of positions and through multidirectional planes of movement.
“Over the last two years we’ve been observing unusual gains in motor function in children participating in our functional Clinical Pilates program,” says Jodie.

“Whilst there is no known published research in Australia on the effects and benefits of using this Reformer in children with disability, we have observed a significant improvement in the children’s physical progress after using the specially tailored machine. We hope to collect enough data before, during and after the program to help us gather additional evidence related to this important clinical intervention for children and young adults with disabilities.

Georgia Farnan (pictured) is a 5 year old who has made significant improvements using the Pilates reformer at Wize Therapy. Diagnosed with Spastic Diplegia Cerebral Palsy, Georgia has gone from being solely reliant on her walker, to using quadsticks and – at times – even standing hands free.

“The confidence in her movements through increased coordination, strength and flexibility has allowed her to participate in more playground activities more often,” says mother Claire Gardiner. “Her teacher stopped the class to watch Georgia climb the stairs and go down the slide on her own for the first time.”

The Jon and Barry Brealey Trust was set up by Ailsa and Bert Brealey in the name of their two sons, both of whom lived their lives with neurological disease Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. Each September, the trustees publish an invitation for agencies or organisations to apply for a grant with the only restriction on the use of grant money that it must be used to benefit people with disabilities.
“We are hoping to continue to support projects for people with disabilities with money from the trust for as long as we can,” says John King, Chairman of the Trust.

Wize Therapy in Booragoon provides physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech pathology services to promote development, achievement and participation for children, adolescents and young adults. The White Zebra Foundation is their not-for-profit arm, providing financial assistance for those who cannot afford these much-needed services for their children.

Qigong Sensory Training (QST) is a massage protocol, which has been developed over the course of 14 years, with 21 scientific studies. QST is based on Chinese medicine and has been used for over 3,000 years to treat medical conditions and improve health in children!

QST is a patting massage and is designed to improve circulation of the skin and the rest of the body. It is quite different from western massage! The direction of the massage is done away from the head, towards the hands and feet, and thus follows the direction of blood flow and brings oxygenated blood to the skin and sensory nerves.

Chinese medicine believes that children with Autism and/or sensory challenges are often less aware of their environment and of their bodies because they have blockages in the sensory channels. This affects the way that a child can take in information from the environment. QST treatment uses a massage protocol to stimulate recovery and growth of tactile fibres by increasing circulation to the skin.

Touch is the first sensory system to develop in babies, and is vital for establishing the infant-caregiver bond that becomes the foundation for self-regulation and social-emotional development. Through frequent and daily holding, feeding, dressing, grooming, and playing, parents and caregivers provide their babies with a wealth of sensory stimulation. During the first years of life, touch is the most important sensation for social connection and self-regulation.

When the tactile system does not work well, children often experience discomfort with clothing, grooming, and/or food textures. They may also have difficulty managing behaviours, difficulty with motor development and social-emotional delays. Without the ability to enjoy touch and close physical contact, children aren’t socially receptive and can’t be soothed by parent touch. Before long, social delay and abnormal behaviour are evident.

Studies show that almost all children on the Autism Spectrum have abnormal processing of tactile and other sensory information. Children without ASD may also have mild to significant sensory processing difficulties, which are impacting on their daily functioning.
QST has a protocol for children with ASD and those with sensory challenges, as well as a different protocol for children who have Cerebral Palsy and Down Syndrome.

Deborah Thomas, one of our Senior Occupational Therapists, has successfully completed the Child Therapist and Parent Training course for Qigong Sensory Training, which allows her to be a trainer and crucial support for families using this massage protocol.
For more information on this exciting intervention for children and their families, please contact Deborah Thomas at WizeTherapy on (08) 9317 7932.

Sending your child to school for the first time, whilst exciting, is a big step for both you and your child! It is normal for parents to have many questions and worries running through their minds. The following are five tips to help ensure your child experiences a successful transition to Kindy in 2017!
You want to ensure little fingers can successfully manage lunchbox lids, containers and packets without support from an adult.
Think about the types of food you will pack your child:
Sandwich – A sandwich wrapped in cling wrap may be more difficult to manage than a sandwich in a snap lock bag or a small container.
Yoghurt – How easy is the lid to open? Will it spill out if little fingers push too hard? Can your child successfully use a spoon to eat it, or would a squeeze tube be easier?

Fruit – Think about whether your child can peel the piece of fruit (i.e. banana) or whether the child can bite straight into the fruit (i.e. apple). If you suspect your child may have difficulties consider whether you can pack bite sized fruit pieces instead.

Find a drink bottle that your child can easily recognize! You may like to choose it for the colour, size or a particular symbol on it. Find a drink bottle t your child can easily open and close, and manage drinking from easily, without coughing or spillage.
This may mean trialing different options over the summer holidays to determine which bottle works best. This will make sure your child stays well hydrated throughout the Kindy day!

Allow your child to have practice runs of eating their school lunch. A great way to do this is to go to the park, and allow your child to practice eating typical foods you are planning on packing for school. Make sure you bring your own lunch in a lunchbox to provide a model for your child!

This practice will give you a great opportunity to watch how your child goes with managing opening and closing their lunchbox, manipulating food packets and having a drink from their drink bottle. This is a great time to also model social expectations such as sitting down with crossed legs to eat lunch and placing rubbish in the bin.

Once you have purchased your child’s school uniform, make sure your child practices wearing it for extended periods of time. This will give you a good opportunity to see if your child has any sensitivity to the uniform, such as itchy seams or tags. It may help to soften the uniform by washing it a few times.

Another helpful skill is for your child to be able to manage pulling their pants and underwear on and off when going to the toilet at school. If the uniform has difficult buttons and zips, an elastic can be added to allow for increased independence with taking pants on and off for toileting.

Drive past the school during the summer holidays and talk about what will happen there! If you know of any children who will be in your child’s Kindy class, try and organise a playdate over the summer break.

The beginning of Kindy marks a time in a child’s life where their independence and confidence begins to flourish separate from their parents. Be kind to yourself and your child and embrace the new experiences as you both embark on the next step in your child’s journey in life!

The April School Holidays are a great time to build on all that your child has learnt throughout the year and support your child’s progress with their reading. I’ve put together a few activities and strategies to help parents or caregivers support their child’s reading and early literacy skills.

A child requires both knowledge of the alphabet and phonological awareness to learn to read and spell. So, what is phonological awareness (PA)? When we are talking about PA, we are talking about the child’s ability to identify individual spoken words in a sentence and similarly, individual syllables or sounds within a spoken word. In other words, PA is the child’s awareness of the sound structure of words. PA is important as children who can hear the individual sounds in a word, have greater success when starting to read and “sound out” words.

To read a word, children need to understand that a word is made up of separate letters. Children should be able to identify each letter of the alphabet – both the name of the letter and the sound the letter makes to start to read. For example, when a child is learning the letter “S” they should know that “The name of the letter is “S” and it makes the /ssss/ sound.”
Here are a few fun ideas to help your child’s reading and literacy skills blossom!
Activities to help learn the letter name and sounds of the alphabet:

Remember this is a learning activity and not a test. Children should always be supported in their learning; you should always be modelling the correct letter or sound. If your child makes an error, let them know immediately. For example, if your child mistakes a b for a d, let them know both verbally and visually, e.g. “oh this is the letter “d” and it makes the /d/ sound and it looks like this, a letter “b”, makes a /b/ sound, and it looks like this”. Learning can be fun and educational with a positive experience attached to it. Why not try these activities with your children during the April School Holidays!

Bubbles are a fun, portable, mesmerising and a number one go-to toy for Speech Pathologists, Occupational Therapists and Physiotherapists alike! Bubbles are engaging, motivating and can be used to encourage all aspects of communication, social, fine motor and gross motor development.
Here are 21 bubble games which you can play to support your child’s early development today!

: Practice popping the bubbles at your child’s skill level. You can pop the bubbles by waving your hands in the air, grabbing with your whole hand, using your index finger (pointer finger), clicking, flicking or pinching the bubbles! Use your imagination; you can even try catching the bubbles with a spoon!
If your child has difficulty popping floating bubbles, catch one on the bubble wand and then pop it.
Follow a bubble’s flight with a flashlight or a laser pen. To make it easier, just watch where the bubbles go together. Can you watch them until they pop?
Encourage your child to pop the bubbles with one hand only. This will mean your child will have to reach across their body to pop the bubbles on the opposite side.
: Clap the bubbles to pop them, or pop them using both pointer fingers together!

Get your child to use his/her helper hand to hold the bubble tube, and the dominant hand to dip the bubble wand or unscrew the cap. If your child has not yet established a dominant hand, you can practice swapping hands!

A handy trick to work out which hand your child is beginning to favour as a dominant hand, is to hold the bubble tube out towards the middle of your child’s chest. See which hand your child favours to reach out and take the bubbles with.

Mix a small amount of food colouring in the bubble liquid. Give your child a canvas or thick piece of paper to try and catch the bubbles on. Your child can draw a picture over the bubble art, scribble or practice writing their name for extra fine motor practice.

The physical act of blowing can be a very effective sensory-based way to help your child calm, organise and focus the body. How long can your child keep the bubbles in the air by blowing underneath them? Practice taking a deep breath and blowing bubbles into the air on the exhalation. Quietly watch the bubbles float away together.

Encourage your child to chase the bubbles while walking/crawling through different sensations. Try long grass, sand, rice, shaving foam, carpet, wet floor etc. Touching bubbles is also a sensory experience in itself!

Have your child sit or stand on an uneven surface while trying to pop the bubbles. Your child could sit or stand on a pillow or sofa cushion, stand in a sand pit, sit on a gym ball or even stand on a wobble board!

Place some obstacle course equipment around the room (pillows, sofa cushions, balls, chairs, small tables, tunnel etc.) and blow the bubbles over and under them. Your child then needs to navigate the items to pop the bubbles!

Wait for the bubbles to land on the floor and then pop them! Depending on your child’s skill level kick them, crawl through them, stomp them, jump or hop on them or even wheelbarrow walk through them.
Dance through the bubbles but remember to freeze when the music stops! Make the music pause longer to encourage your child to freeze for longer.
Put some music on and have a bubble dance party! Have a set space where the children can dance. A piece of carpet or a masking tape square on the floor works well. Try not to bump into each other!

One child holds a hula-hoop in the air and the other child must blow the bubble through the circle! Both children must work together to score a goal! You can make this game more difficult by playing on a windy day or with a fan in the room.
Provide one bubble blower between children. Stay present to help your child navigate the rules of sharing and taking turns.

Hide the bubble blower around the house. Give your child clues to find it by describing the function of the object it is in or next to. For example ‘It is in something that keeps our food cold’ or ‘it’s where you sleep!’
Who can you blow a bubble to? You get extra points for popping the bubble on them! To Dad or Mum? To me or you? Is it your turn or my turn? Is it her turn or his turn?
Bubbles is a perfect toy to encourage your child to request or ask for help. Try any of the following tricks to encourage communication.
1. Blow some bubbles, put the lid back on and WAIT.
2. Put the bubble blower in sight but out of reach (i.e. up on the kitchen bench).
3. Put the lid on very tightly and then hand the bubble blower to your child. WAIT.
4. Take a deep breath as if you are about to blow the bubbles and WAIT.
5. Say ‘Ready, Set, Go!’ when you blow the bubbles. On the next turn, say ‘Ready, Set…’ and WAIT.

Remember the WAIT until your child communicates with you. This could be by vocalising, making eye contact, reaching towards the bubbles, signing, hand leading, putting the bubbles in your hand, saying a word or a whole sentence!

Invest in a set of bubble blowers that look different. They might differ by colour, size or shape of the bubble blower. Talk about what the bubbles look like and where the bubbles are floating to! Are the bubbles floating up or down? Are they big bubbles or little bubbles?
If your child is learning more difficult describing words, talk about and demonstrate the following concepts: wet/dry, fast/slow, full/empty and clean/dirty.

Blow bubbles during bath time onto your little one’s body, and name the body parts that they land on together. Bubbles will sit longer on wet skin before popping, so bath-time makes the perfect time for learning body parts!

Give your child instructions on how to pop the bubbles with each turn. You can clap them, poke them, kick them, pinch them or jump on them! The possibilities are endless! Make the instructions more difficult by giving your child a sequence of movements to follow.

We all know that reading books to your child is good for their development. The question is however, how do we make sure that we are doing so in a way that is maximising their opportunities for language learning? The answer is book sharing.
What is book sharing and why do we do it?

Book sharing is all about engaging and involving your child in the book reading process. Instead of merely reading a book to your child word for word while they listen, you are making yourself and your child active participants.
It will come as no surprise to you that book sharing has a number of benefits such as helping to:
So how do we successfully book share?
These are my top tips for optimising language learning through book sharing:
Show an interest in the stories that you are reading. If your child can see that you are excited, they will generally want to share that excitement with you.

Put on ‘silly’ voices or even create voices for story characters. Use facial expressions and gestures to make the story more appealing. Sit in a way that ensures you and your child can both see the book, and your child can also see your face and body. A ‘triangle’ set up often works well.
For example, if you are reading a book about farm animals, get out a farm set and animals to make the experience more real.
4. Involve the child by letting them lift the flaps, turn the pages etc
This will help to maintain their attention and level of engagement.
5. Talk about the pictures in the story, you can even make up parts of the story and encourage your child to do so as well.
6. Relate what is happening in the book to experiences your child has had.
For example, if the book is about the beach, talk about times when you have been to the beach and what you have seen and/or done there.

Book sharing is especially great for those ‘Wh’ questions such who, what, when, where and why. On any particular page you could ask “what is happening?”, “where is X?” or “why is X …?” It is important to remember that this is not a test. If your child is unable to answer a question, simply provide them with the answer. This is how they will learn!
8. Encourage your child to ask questions about what they are hearing!
This will provide opportunity to expand their knowledge even further.
9. Read and re-read the same stories over and over again.
Repetition is key for helping children to learn language!

It is never too early (or too late) to start book sharing. It is helpful to make book sharing part of your every day routine. Pick a time that is best for your family, such as before your child goes to bed. Lastly, don’t be afraid to check out your local library!

December is well and truly upon us now! If you are anything like me, you have barely even started a list for your Christmas gift shopping, let alone made it to the shops yet! If your circle of family and friends includes any little ones who still need a helping hand with their language learning, here’s a list of some of my favourite toys and games that would be perfect. These toys and games are not only fun and colourful, they are perfect for a range of ages and language levels!

This is one of my favourite games to use during therapy sessions, and one that is well-loved by the kids and parents too! There hasn’t been a time that I’ve played it where everyone in the room hasn’t been laughing. While it’s not the traditional way of playing the game, I love to use Headbandz to target describing skills. The kids get to choose which card goes on your headband (and they think they are absolutely hilarious) and then give you clues to help you guess what it is. The little ones may need some help with providing the clues initially- which makes it the perfect sibling or whole family game!
Hedbanz can be purchased at Target for only $20! Find it

If you haven’t had a look at any of the products by Orchard Toys, do it now! They have a huge range of games that incorporate lots of learning areas like counting, colours, language and literacy. I like to use Red Dog Blue Dog for identifying colours, encouraging 2-5 word sentences and turn-taking. So many uses for just one game!
Red Dog Blue Dog can be purchased online at Village Toys for a discounted price of $34.95. Take a look

These boards are another great gift idea that can be used to target many different areas- improving vocabulary, following instructions, giving instructions and telling stories! The products come with a felt play board and assorted felt pieces that can be stuck onto the play board in an endless number of ways. The boards are available in a number of themes to suit all interests, including; farm animals, Disney princesses, outer space and safari to name a few. If you have plans to take any road or plane trips over the holidays, these would also be a great travel activity!
A variety of Fuzzy-Felt products can be purchased through Fishpond with FREE shipping! Take a look

Toys such as tea sets, kitchens, doctor kits, tool bags and baby play sets are awesome little additions to your gift list. Not only will the kids be entertained for hours; they are constantly using their imaginations and giving you opportunities to model longer sentences or new words for them to learn. And you never know, you might just be inspiring their future careers!
Toys “R” Us stock a great selection of playsets at a range of prices to suit your budget. Have a look at their selection

If you are or have ever been involved in the Speech Pathology world then I’m sure you have come across this game! Pop up Pirate is a very simple turn-taking game where you stick the swords into a barrel and wait for pirate to POP. The element of surprise (never knowing when the pop is going to happen!) is what keeps this game interesting and a favourite of many kids. Although it is simple, it can be used to work on turn taking skills, basic colour identification, encouraging longer sentences and requesting!
Pop-up Pirate can be purchased at Big W for only $12! View
Wishing you all a safe, fun-filled Christmas and New Year!
